abstracts.cdata!:
The Capacity Building for Decentralized
            Service Delivery Project for Ethiopia has a satisfactory
            outcome and a low or negligible risk to development outcome.
            Both the Bank and the borrower performances were moderately
            satisfactory. The main lessons learned from the project are:
            1) Designing a project that fits government implementation
            capacity will help ensure its effectiveness and timely
            implementation. 2) Intensively supervising projects with
            innovative designs and a dynamic context is critical to
            address issues that are not foreseen at the time of
            preparation. 3) Setting procurement thresholds too low can
            delay implementation of infrastructure projects. 4)
            Intensive supervision of the design and implementation of
            urban governments infrastructure projects is essential in
            the early years to ensure that works are of adequate quality
            and that funds are used effectively. 5) Conducting periodic
            client satisfaction surveys at facilities can both focus
            staff on enhancing quality of service delivery and help them
            to understand and overcome obstacles in doing so. 6)
            Thoroughly preparing a project monitoring and evaluation
            system prior to the start of a project will ensure that
            stakeholders can track progress towards the project
            objectives as soon as implementation starts.
